summary: This document is a series of emails from Christopher J. Dilorio, a self-proclaimed whistleblower, sent between November 2020 and December 2020. The emails allege widespread corruption, obstruction, and criminal facilitation by the SEC, FINRA, and other financial institutions, specifically protecting entities like Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial (NITE) involved in money laundering, naked short selling, and fraud via OTC markets and shell companies. Dilorio references his own TCR (Tip, Complaint, or Referral) submissions and claims the SEC uses his information for selective enforcement while shielding key players.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making extensive allegations of SEC, FINRA, and financial institution corruption related to market manipulation, money laundering, and obstruction of justice. Claims to have submitted TCRs detailing these activities.

persons.name: Jane
persons.context: Addressed repeatedly in emails, appears to be an SEC official (possibly Jane Norberg) whom Dilorio accuses of lying and obstructing his whistleblower claims.

persons.name: Richard Best
persons.context: Named as Director of SEC NY, associated with the FINRA action against Brown Brothers Harriman. Dilorio claims he left entities unnamed in complaints to protect executing broker-dealers like NITE.

persons.name: Robert Sollazzo
persons.role: Broker-Dealer Exam Program Leader (SEC NY OCIE)
persons.context: Retired SEC official accused by Dilorio of obstructing investigations into criminal broker-dealers like NITE during his 38-year tenure.

persons.name: Michael Rufino
persons.role: Associate Director of OCIE's Broker-Dealer Examination Program (SEC NY)
persons.context: Former FINRA executive who joined the SEC NY office. Dilorio alleges he, like Richard Best, did nothing to stop fraud during his 32 years at FINRA and is part of the SEC cover-up.

persons.name: Sigal Mandelker
persons.role: Former Treasury Under Secretary for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence
persons.context: Mentioned for her 2019 audit report condemning Russian money laundering in key US economic sectors. Dilorio implies her non-replacement was due to the report's findings.

persons.name: Dan Kamensky
persons.context: Referenced as a defendant in a case brought by the SDNY. Dilorio claims the case is a fraud and that Kamensky is being set up due to a corrupt relationship between the SEC/SDNY and Jefferies.

persons.name: Richard Handler
persons.context: Portrayed as having a corrupt, criminal relationship with the SEC/SDNY. Allegedly a primary beneficiary of frauds and cover-ups related to Knight/KCG/Virtu Financial.

persons.name: Douglas Cifu
persons.context: CEO of Virtu Financial (NITE). Accused of admitting retail/OTC market trading drives revenue while omitting this from SEC filings, and of participating in fraudulent mergers and accounting.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: SEC Chairman accused of gross corruption, conflicts of interest (via Sullivan & Cromwell ties to NITE), and facilitating frauds while screwing whistleblowers.

persons.name: Glenn Hutchins
persons.role: Co-founder of Silver Lake, North Island
persons.context: Former Blackstone executive, bought SunGard, co-founded North Island with Robert Greifeld. North Island is a top shareholder in NITE/Virtu. Implicated in money laundering connections via SunGard's Russian ruble conversion technology.

persons.name: Robert Greifeld
persons.context: Former NASDAQ CEO, co-founded North Island with Glenn Hutchins. Linked to SunGard, BRUT ECN, and automated ruble-to-dollar conversion technology implicated in money laundering.

persons.name: Adena Friedman
persons.context: Current NASDAQ CEO who signed off on the BRUT ECN transaction. NASDAQ is implicated as a repository for AQR blank check shells used for money laundering.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Referenced as a 'bag man' involved in fraudulent convertible note assignments and pump-and-dump schemes, including with JMJ and entities like Blink Charging. Barred by FINRA.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.context: Referenced as a 'bag man' involved in fraudulent note assignments through Hanover/Magna, implicated in SEC complaints related to NewLead, FreeSeas, etc.

persons.name: Ebrahim Daoud Nonoo
persons.context: Identified as a new 'bag man' involved with the money laundering shell AppTech and its deal with NEC Payments in Bahrain.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Sullivan & Cromwell colleague of Jay Clayton. Accused of playing a key role in keeping NITE/Virtu operational and involved in fraudulent transactions.

persons.name: Jane Norberg
persons.role: SEC Office of the Whistleblower Chief
persons.context: Referenced indirectly as part of the OWB. Accused of providing false reasons for denying Dilorio's award, including the claim that 'SEC investigators never saw my information.'

persons.name: Preet Bharara
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney for the SDNY
persons.context: Mentioned as having been in possession of Dilorio's information while at the SDNY.

persons.name: Judge Caproni
persons.context: Addressed in an email regarding the Dan Kamensky case, which Dilorio claims is a fraud on the court.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Addressed in an email applauding her reproof of the SONY and urging her to look at the Dan Kamensky case.

persons.name: Judge Cave
persons.context: Addressed in multiple emails regarding the Dan Kamensky case and the corrupt relationship between the SEC/Handler/Jefferies.

persons.name: Judge Jones
persons.context: Addressed in emails alongside Judge Cave regarding the Dan Kamensky case and SEC corruption.

persons.name: Alexander Blostein
persons.context: Goldman Sachs analyst referenced for his modeling of NITE/Virtu. Accused of knowing OTCM share volumes drive revenue but omitting this from his models.

persons.name: Richard Repetto
persons.context: Sell-side analyst referenced in the context of questions about NITE/Virtu's red flags and OTCM volumes.

persons.name: Steven Mnuchin
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Trump for not replacing Sigal Mandelker and rewriting the Treasury org structure.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Mnuchin for not replacing Sigal Mandelker.

connections.description: Dilorio is the whistleblower sending allegations and appeals to Jane, an SEC official, whom he accuses of lying and obstruction.
Alleged corrupt, criminal relationship where the SEC under Clayton protects Handler/Jefferies and facilitates frauds involving NITE/KCG.
Handler (Jefferies) and Cifu (Virtu) orchestrated the VIRT/KCG merger, which Dilorio claims was fraudulent and involved writing down billions in naked short fails.
Co-founded North Island, a top shareholder in NITE/Virtu. Connected via SunGard's sale and technology for real-time ruble-to-dollar conversion.
Both are from Sullivan & Cromwell. Fishman is accused of playing a key role in keeping NITE/Virtu operational, indicating a conflict of interest for Clayton.
Both are described as 'bag men' involved in fraudulent convertible note assignments and pump-and-dump schemes related to shell companies.
Both are SEC NY officials with prior ties to FINRA. Dilorio alleges they work together to protect entities like NITE by leaving them unnamed in enforcement actions.
Kamensky is a defendant in a case where Jefferies (Handler) is the investment bank. Dilorio claims the case is a fraudulent set-up to protect Handler/Jefferies.
Dilorio's whistleblower award claims are processed by the SEC OWB, headed by Norberg, whom he accuses of fabricating denials and obstructing.

events.title: Knight Capital 'Glitch'
events.description: Knight Capital suffered a massive trading loss due to a software 'glitch,' which Dilorio claims exposed Knight's insolvency and was a cover-up for its core business of abusive naked short selling.

events.title: Virtu Financial-KCG Merger Closing
events.description: Virtu Financial acquired KCG Holdings in a $1.4 billion all-cash transaction. Dilorio alleges the SEC, Handler, and Cifu orchestrated the merger, writing down over $4 billion in leverage and fraud assets to hide KCG's insolvency.

events.title: NASDAQ Acquires Verafin
events.description: NASDAQ announced a $2.8 billion acquisition of Verafin, a financial crimes/money laundering detection firm. Dilorio cites this as evidence of a massive money laundering problem within NASDAQ-listed entities.

events.title: Dilorio's Final Appeal and Allegations
events.description: Dilorio sends emails asserting that NITE/Virtu remains insolvent due to ongoing abusive naked shorting and that the SEC's preliminary denial of his whistleblower award is part of a clock-running obstruction scheme.

events.title: Dilorio's Initial TCR Submission
events.description: Christopher Dilorio filed his initial TCR (Tip, Complaint, or Referral) with SEC official Berger, detailing allegations of corruption, money laundering, and naked short selling involving Knight Capital and related entities.

events.title: Sigal Mandelker's Audit Report
events.description: Treasury Under Secretary Sigal Mandelker released audit report OIG-19-033, a scathing condemnation of Russian money laundering in key US economic sectors. Dilorio implies her non-replacement was retaliation.

keyFacts: Christopher Dilorio alleges a vast, ongoing conspiracy where the SEC, FINRA, and financial institutions (like Jefferies and Virtu) protect criminal enterprises like Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu (NITE) involved in money laundering and naked short selling via OTC shell companies.

Dilorio claims the SEC uses his whistleblower information to bring selective enforcement actions (e.g., against Sason, Keener, BBH) while intentionally shielding the primary executing broker-dealer NITE and its executives.
The 2012 Knight 'glitch' and 2017 Virtu-KCG merger are presented as orchestrated cover-ups to hide insolvency stemming from NITE's core business of abusive naked short selling and accounting fraud.

Dilorio implicates high-level connections, including SEC Chair Jay Clayton's alleged conflicts via Sullivan & Cromwell, and a corrupt relationship between the SEC/SDNY and Jefferies CEO Richard Handler.

The emails reference specific shell companies and fraud mechanisms, such as Net Element (NETE), Blink Charging (BLNK), AppTech, and AQR blank check shells, as examples of money laundering vehicles actively facilitated by SEC obstruction.
